{{talkheader}} {{WikiProject Christianity|class=c|importance=Mid|catholicism=yes|catholicism-importance=High}} {{WikiProject Vatican City|class=c|importance=Top}} == What is the difference? == It isn't very clear as to how the [[Holy See]] and the State of the [[Vatican City]] are different. You say they are repeatedly in both articles, but you don't explain how. Could you please clarify this? Thank you for your time and understanding.--[[User:CafeDelKevin|CafeDelKevin]] ([[User talk:CafeDelKevin|talk]]) 05:30, 23 January 2010 (UTC) :The Holy See is not a city, Vatican City is. Though headed by the same person, they are in reality as different as the Archdiocese of New York and New York City are. So too the Church of England is distinct from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, though headed by the same individual. [[User:Esoglou|Esoglou]] ([[User talk:Esoglou|talk]]) 08:38, 23 January 2010 (UTC) ::Yeah, basically, the Holy See is an institution, the Vatican City is a tiny state that the institution has control over. The Holy See could, and did, exist without the State of the Vatican City, and countries could, and did, have diplomatic relations with the Holy See without it having a state. --[[User:Cam|Cam]] ([[User talk:Cam|talk]]) 14:02, 23 January 2010 (UTC) :::Holy See is a collective term for all territories and people that the Church has control over, Vatican City is where the operations are based in. [[User:InTheRevolution2|InTheRevolution2]] ([[User talk:InTheRevolution2|talk]]) 20:05, 20 December 2011 (UTC) == Nazi Gold in see also. == Greetings, i have since added 'nazi gold' into the 'See Also' area of the article as it is well documented (even on other wikipedia pages such as the vatican city bank page) that the vatican has several hundred million dollars worth of nazi gold for 'safekeeping'. I therefore thought it important to list 'nazi gold' on the 'see also' section of the article as it is related. Kind regards, anon. —Preceding [[Wikipedia:Signatures|unsigned]] comment added by [[Special:Contributions/78.145.151.2|78.145.151.2]] ([[User talk:78.145.151.2|talk]]) 16:17, 6 March 2010 (UTC) == sovereignty recognition? == We have the list of 178 countries recognizing the Holy See as sovereign, established diplomatic relations, etc. But are there other states, that do '''not''' recognize it as sovereign entity? Reading [http://chiesa.espresso.repubblica.it/articolo/1341731?eng=y this] makes me think that there aren't such, but still, having in mind the [[Legal status of the Holy See|special status]] of the Holy See and the related [[Vatican City State]], I think it would be good to have such info confirmed (like we have the [[Recognition of Israel|"states do not recognize Israel as a state"]] - there the list of countries with no "established relations/suspended relations/withdrawn their recognition" is separate from the list of countries that do not recognize it "as state"). Also, [[Foreign relations of the Holy See]] states - "The Holy See maintains formal diplomatic relations with 178 sovereign states, the European Union, and the Sovereign Military Order of Malta, and has relations of a special nature with the Palestine Liberation Organization.[12] The Holy See maintains '''179''' permanent diplomatic missions abroad, of which 73 are non-residential, so that it '''has in all 106 concrete missions''', some of which are accredited not only to the country in which they are situated, but also to one or more other countries or international organizations.", and this contradicts [[List of diplomatic missions of the Holy See]] and [[Nuncio]] - where there are more than 106 (but less than 179). It seems that there are two types of recognizing states: #Recognizing Holy See as sovereign entity, regardless of its status as "state" (the Vatican City) #Recognizing Holy See "as government" (maybe not the proper term) of sovereign state (the Vatican City) only, but not as "non-state sovereign entity" Here, partial list could be made by the states that recognized it before the 1929 Vatican City establishment. About the diplomatic missions - it is clear, that out of the 181 entities (178 + EU, SMOM, PLO) with relations (but there is also the [[Talk:List_of_diplomatic_missions_in_Palestine#Consulates-General in Jerusalem|non state Jerusalem mission]], so maybe there are totaly 182 "locations"?), some do not get even a non-resident diplomat (no accreditation) - if the 179 number is correct. But, as there is no clear distinction in the [[List of diplomatic missions of the Holy See|missions of]] article about resident and non-resident missions it is impossible to check. It would be helpful to have: #List of physical missions with accredited resident diplomat #List of entities that have non-resident diplomat accredited (and where he is based) #Clarification if the Jerusalem mission is accredited to PLO or there is a separate mission (based in Jerusalem/Ramallah/Gaza?) or PLO is one of the no-accreditation entities) #Clarification if there is physical mission (Rome based) or non-resident diplomat accredited to SMOM (and where is he based, if non-resident) #Clarification if there is physical mission (Brussels based) or non-resident diplomat accredited to EU (and where is he based, if non-resident) Connected with the above and with the sovereignty recognition is the issue of non-diplomatic (eg. Catholic Church only) representatives. [http://chiesa.espresso.repubblica.it/articolo/1341731?eng=y As it seems] there are: #The 178 (including Cook Islands, Taiwan [http://www.vatican.va/news_services/press/documentazione/documents/corpo-diplomatico/corpo-diplomatico_stati_elenco_en.html]) + EU, SMOM - diplomatic relations established #The PLO - special relations #Jerusalem - special mission #Somalia (SMOM relations), Brunei, Malaysia - "there are apostolic delegates, pontifical representatives to the local Catholic communities but not to the government.", "formal contact" #Comoros (SMOM relations), Mauritania (SMOM relations), Laos, Myanmar - "there are apostolic delegates, pontifical representatives to the local Catholic communities but not to the government." #Afghanistan (SMOM relations), Oman (in process of establishing relations), and Vietnam (in process of establishing relations) - "formal contact" #PR China - "semi-official contacts" #Saudi Arabia - "Catholic worship is still officially prohibited", [[Holy See-Saudi Arabia relations|"Islamic Vatican"]], but nevertheless "formal contact" #Bhutan, North Korea, Tuvalu, Niue, Kosovo ("whose international status is still controversial" - like others with [[List of states with limited recognition|limited recogntion]]) - nothing in the link #Maldives - "priests are not even allowed to come to assist the many Catholic tourists present in the archipelago" It would be good if we can find sources showing if some of these ~17 countries do '''not''' recognize the Holy See as sovereign, but maybe there are none, as even Saudi Arabia looks to work with it. The respective post about SMOM recognition is [[Talk:Sovereign_Military_Order_of_Malta#sovereignity_recognition.3F|here]]. [[User:Alinor|Alinor]] ([[User talk:Alinor|talk]]) 17:37, 28 July 2010 (UTC) :You have put too many questions for me to digest. Would you please begin by distinguishing between recognizing a state and having diplomatic relations with it. The Holy See recognizes Saudi Arabia: when one of that kingdom's rulers is received by the Pope, the announcement of the audience mentions the kingdom. This contrasts with the situation, at least in the past, in one would-be-Marxist state in Africa which refused to recognize the Republic of Korea: the official media in the country were not allowed to give news about that state but only about "the southern part of Korea"! You need more than the absence of diplomatic relations with the Holy See to conclude that any particular state denies the sovereignty of the Holy See. :If you wish, I will try to answer your questions tomorrow, but only one at a time. Which one? That is what the post is about. To find out IF there are such cases - to find sources showing "more than the absence of diplomatic relations" IF at all there are such (or as there are only a few states without diplomatic relations - to find the opposite sources showing that they don't deny the sovereignty of the Holy See; even better if explicitly mentioned if they relate this to Vatican City state or not - but I think sources with such distinction would be impossible to find). ::Questions. Recognition is generally implicit, not express, and this implicit recognition is of a [[subject of international law]], an entity that one interrelates with in public international law, and so, in that sense, a sovereign entity, whether it is a state or not. I have difficulty in believing that any could possibly classify the Holy See as a state. [[User:Esoglou|Esoglou]] ([[User talk:Esoglou|talk]]) 16:51, 10 January 2011 (UTC) :The expected announcement about Vietnam has come today. The "non-resident papal representative to Vietnam" (neither a nuncio nor an apostolic delegate, and so something like what there was until recently in Russia, except that that representative was resident) is the nuncio to Indonesia, who has had his remit extended to cover Brunei, Malaysia and Singapore also, areas that have been removed from the care of the papal representative to Thailand. That means that the list above requires adjustments to line 48, which becomes: :Indonesia* >''Brunei Darussalam''^ >''Malaysia''^ =Singapore* >Timor Est* >Vietnam(Non-Resident Papal Representative); :and to line 93, which becomes: :Thailandia* >Cambogia* >''Laos''^ >''Myanmar''^ == Merge: Holy Roman Church == The article [[Holy Roman Church]] seems to me unnecessary. The article itself states that it is the same thing as the [[Diocese of Rome]] or the [[Holy See]]. The only purpose the article itself seems to serve is to define yet another term (which violates [[WP:NAD]]). Given that there does not appear to be a unique topic to be discussed there I propose merging here. --[[User:Mcorazao|Mcorazao]] ([[User talk:Mcorazao|talk]]) 15:47, 30 July 2010 (UTC) :P.S. Anticipating a possible concern, even to the extent that ''Holy Roman Church'' could be argued to discuss something unique, the question is whether that topic is distinct enough to merit a separate article from [[Roman Catholic Church]], [[Diocese of Rome]], or [[Holy See]]. Any subtle distinction that could be argued to exist -- I believe -- is better covered in one of the other articles. --[[User:Mcorazao|Mcorazao]] ([[User talk:Mcorazao|talk]]) 18:06, 30 July 2010 (UTC) ::It seems to me that the term is ambiguous as it could refer to three separate articles. I think in that case, turning it into a disambiguation page is the most proper course of action. [[User:Gentgeen|Gentgeen]] ([[User talk:Gentgeen|talk]]) 08:02, 5 August 2010 (UTC) :::I can support that. Any objections to converting to a disambig? --[[User:Mcorazao|Mcorazao]] ([[User talk:Mcorazao|talk]]) 20:54, 6 August 2010 (UTC) ==So what is it?== No where, not here, nor on the "politics: forms of government" page, is there a description of what the Holy See is. I.e., constitutional, parlementary, theocracy? Nor is there a "clean cut" description of the difference between the Roman Curia and the College of Cardinals. Since Holy See is so-called a "sovereign entity", Vatican City is no longer a sovereign entity. ––[[User:虞海|虞海{{#if:{{NAMESPACE}} | | [[Category:Articles containing {{#switch:zh |ar = Arabic |es = Spanish |de = German |fr = French |ja = Japanese |zh = Chinese |bg = Bulgarian |cs = Czech |da = Danish |nl = Dutch |et = Estonian |fi = Finnish |el = Greek |hu = Hungarian |ga = Irish |grc = Ancient Greek |la|lat = Latin |cy = Welsh |sl = Slovene |slv = Slovene |en|eng = explicitly cited English |#default = {{#ifexist:Category:Articles containing {{ISO 639 name zh}} language text |{{ISO 639 name zh}} |non-English }} }} language text]] }} (Yú Hǎi)]] 15:48, 16 October 2010 (UTC) :Holy See seems to be a [[ruling party|ruling entity]] of Vatican, and a [[ruling party|ruling entity]] does not have the sovereignty. ––[[User:虞海|虞海{{#if:{{NAMESPACE}} | | [[Category:Articles containing {{#switch:zh |ar = Arabic |es = Spanish |de = German |fr = French |ja = Japanese |zh = Chinese |bg = Bulgarian |cs = Czech |da = Danish |nl = Dutch |et = Estonian |fi = Finnish |el = Greek |hu = Hungarian |ga = Irish |grc = Ancient Greek |la|lat = Latin |cy = Welsh |sl = Slovene |slv = Slovene |en|eng = explicitly cited English |#default = {{#ifexist:Category:Articles containing {{ISO 639 name zh}} language text |{{ISO 639 name zh}} |non-English }} }} language text]] }} (Yú Hǎi)]] 15:51, 16 October 2010 (UTC) ::Whether the Vatican City State is or is not sovereign (and no reliable source has been cited for its alleged lack of sovereignty), it is not the same entity as the Holy See. Similarly, the fact that the British sovereign is the supreme governor of the Church of England is no ground for merging the Wikipedia articles on these two distinct entities. [[User:Esoglou|Esoglou]] ([[User talk:Esoglou|talk]]) 20:33, 16 October 2010 (UTC) :::I agree, it is like trying to merge [[Paris]] with the [[Government of France]] article. [[User:History2007|History2007]] ([[User talk:History2007|talk]]) 01:16, 18 October 2010 (UTC) '''Oppose.''' The Holy See is an episcopal see – an administrative body of the Church, and its central government. Vatican City is a physical place. You do not go on holidays to the Holy See. You do go on holidays to Vatican City. Diplomatic passports are issued by the Holy See, not Vatican City State. You purchase postage stamps from the [[Philatelic and Numismatic Office of the Vatican City State]], not from the Philatelic and Numismatic Office of the Holy See. They are entirely separate entities. I can't see any good reason for merging the two. – [[User:SMasters|S Masters]] ([[User talk:SMasters|talk]]) 13:45, 17 October 2010 (UTC) : Then we can take an example: You do go on holidays to [[Vietnam]]. Diplomatic passports are issued by the [[Socialist Republic of Vietnam|Socialist Republic]], not Vietnam. You might be attacked by the [[Vietnam People's Army]], not by the Socialist Republic's People's Army. So they're also entirely separate entities. Will you split them? If you don't do it, it would be discrimination to Vietnamese and respectness to Vatican, and is not allowed by NPOV. ––[[User:虞海|虞海 (Yú Hǎi)]] ([[User talk:虞海#top|talk]]) 03:35, 20 October 2010 (UTC) ::Going with your argument, you are advocating that [[Canberra]] be merged into [[Government of Australia]] and [[London]] into [[Government of the United Kingdom]]? - [[User:SMasters|S Masters]] ([[User talk:SMasters|talk]]) 04:24, 20 October 2010 (UTC) :::And sorry, to answer your questions regarding Vietnam, I'm guessing that they are not separate articles because there is not enough content to split them.
